Last Sacrifice (Vampire Academy, #6)-137.groundtruth:
Lissa Dragomir: What's going on? Why the urgent visit?

Ambrose: Because I have to show you something. Remember when I said they were locking off Tatiana's belongings? Well now they're inventorying and removing them. She had a safe where she kept important documents—secret ones, obviously. And...

Lissa Dragomir: And?

Ambrose: And, I didn't want anyone to find them. I didn't know what most of them were, but if she wanted them secret... I just felt they should stay that way. I knew the combination, and so... I stole them.

Lissa Dragomir: And?

Ambrose: None of them have anything to do with what you're looking for... except maybe this one. (hands Lissa the letter)

Environment: The room falls silent as Lissa, Adrian, and Christian read the letter. The tension in the air is palpable as they process its contents.

Christian Ozera: Well. It would seem Tatiana had enemies. But I guess that's kind of obvious at this point in the game.

Adrian Ivashkov: Who's this from? (his face darkens with fury)

Ambrose: I don't know. This is exactly the way I found it. Maybe she didn't even know who the sender was.

Lissa Dragomir: There's certainly an anonymous feel to it... and yet, at the same time, I feel like it's someone Tatiana must have known well.

The Magician’s Nephew (Chronicles of Nar.scenario: In a lush, vibrant land that was once believed to be a dark stable, Tirian, Lucy, and their companions encounter a group of Dwarfs who stubbornly refuse to acknowledge their true surroundings. The air is sweet with the scent of flowers, and the sun shines brightly overhead. However, the Dwarfs remain huddled together, convinced they are still trapped in a pitch-black enclosure. Tirian and Lucy, deeply concerned, attempt to reason with the Dwarfs and show them the beauty around them.
The Magician’s Nephew (Chronicles of Nar.groundtruth:
Lucy Pevensie: Look out! Mind where you're going. Don't walk into our faces!

Diggle: All right! We're not blind. We've got eyes in our heads.

Lucy Pevensie: (picks some wild violets) Listen, Dwarf. Even if your eyes are wrong, perhaps your nose is all right: can you smell that? (holds the flowers to Diggle's nose)

Diggle: (swings his fist) None of that! How dare you! What do you mean by shoving a lot of filthy stable-litter in my face? There was a thistle in it too. It's like your sauce!

Tirian: Earth-man, she is the Queen Lucy, sent hither by Aslan out of the deep past. And it is for her sake alone that I, Tirian, your lawful King, do not cut all your heads from your shoulders, proved and twice-proved traitors that you are.

Diggle: Well if that doesn't beat everything! How can you go on talking all that rot? Your wonderful Lion didn't come and help you, did he? Thought not. And now—even now—when you've been beaten and shoved into this black hole, just the same as the rest of us, you're still at your old game. Starting a new lie!

Tirian: (grabs Diggle) There is no black hole, save in your own fancy, fool. Come out of it. (swings Diggle out of the circle)

Diggle: (runs back to the group) Ow! Ow! What d'you do that for! Banging my face against the wall. You've nearly broken my nose.

Lucy Pevensie: (turns to the others) Oh dear! What are we to do for them?

Environment: Suddenly, the earth trembles. The air grows sweeter, and a bright light flashes behind them. All turn to see Aslan, the great golden Lion, standing before them.

Lucy Pevensie: (through tears) Aslan, could you—will you—do something for these poor Dwarfs?

Aslan: Dearest, I will show you both what I can, and what I cannot, do. (approaches the Dwarfs and gives a low growl)

Diggle: Hear that? That's the gang at the other end of the Stable. Trying to frighten us. They do it with a machine of some kind. Don't take any notice. They won't take us in again!

Aslan: (to Lucy and the others) You see. They will not let us help them. They have chosen cunning instead of belief. Their prison is only in their own minds, yet they are in that prison; and so afraid of being taken in that they can not be taken out. But come, children. I have other work to do.

Bared to You (Crossfire, #1)-93-0.groundtruth:
Eva Cross: You can get her not to sign.

Inheritance (The Inheritance Cycle, #4)-.groundtruth:

Eragon: Thank you, Nar Garzhvog. You didn't need to go to such trouble.

Left Behind (Left Behind, #1)-273-0.scenario: In Petra, a hidden city serving as a refuge during the Tribulation, Rayford Steele lies in his quarters, severely injured from a recent ordeal. Outside, an unprecedented darkness engulfs the sky, signaling the approach of prophesied celestial events. Chaim Rosenzweig, a respected Jewish leader and scholar, sits with Rayford, offering companionship and spiritual insight. The air is thick with anticipation as they prepare to witness what they believe to be the beginning of the Glorious Appearing. Despite his pain, Rayford is determined to observe and understand these momentous events.
Left Behind (Left Behind, #1)-273-0.groundtruth:
Rayford Steele: Have you ever seen blackness so thick?

Chaim Rosenzweig: I have seen many wonders in the last seven years. This is like seeing nothing. But the mere anticipation it engenders causes a buzz from the top of my head to the soles of my shoes.

Environment: Suddenly, lightning rips through the sky, briefly illuminating the clouds.

Rayford Steele: I think I saw a shooting star. I love those.

Chaim Rosenzweig: That was more than a shooting star, which, as you know, is not really a star anyway. What you saw was truly a falling star, maybe a meteor. Soon stars and meteors will fall, but you will only hear them.

Chaim Rosenzweig: Isaiah foretold that the stars of heaven and their constellations would not give their light. The sun will be darkened and the moon will not shine.

Rayford Steele: There's another difference between us, Chaim. I've never been able to memorize like that.

Chaim Rosenzweig: What else have I to do, Rayford? As I say, I was thrust into this position, and the teacher became the student. My former protégé, Dr. Ben-Judah, would not hear of my giving short shrift to the Scriptures.

Environment: The darkness outside intensifies, and the sound of falling meteors becomes more frequent and louder.

Rayford Steele: I so wish I could be out there right now. Why did this have to happen today, of all days?

Chaim Rosenzweig: The leader of the Tribulation Force is not going to start questioning God now, is he? You of all people. You have been delivered by His hand as many times as I have.

Rayford Steele: (laughs) You're right, of course. I shouldn't complain.

Club Dead (Sookie Stackhouse, #3)-102-0.groundtruth:

Maggie: I've always known he was the one, but I can't come with you. I'm married.

Maggie: (steps closer and puts her arms around Biff) I'm sorry.

The Complete Sherlock Holmes-134-0.groundtruth:
Sherlock Holmes: "Watson, I believe we've finally unraveled this most peculiar case."

Dr. John Watson: "Indeed, Holmes? But what of Murdoch? He seemed the likely suspect, and now he's a victim."

Sherlock Holmes: "Precisely, Watson. Murdoch's affliction is the key to solving this mystery. Have you noticed the peculiar pattern of marks on both victims?"

Dr. John Watson: "Yes, those crisscrossed lines. Most unusual."

Sherlock Holmes: "Those marks, my dear Watson, are the signature of a most deadly sea creature - the Cyanea capillata, or Lion's Mane jellyfish."

Dr. John Watson: "A jellyfish? But how, Holmes?"

Sherlock Holmes: "This particular species is known for its potent venom and long tentacles. Both McPherson and Murdoch must have encountered it while swimming."

Dr. John Watson: "And McPherson's last words - 'the Lion's Mane' - he was trying to warn us!"

Sherlock Holmes: "Exactly, Watson. The poor man used his last breath to identify his killer, but we were too unfamiliar with the creature to understand."

Dr. John Watson: "It's remarkable, Holmes. But is this beast still out there, posing a danger?"

Sherlock Holmes: "Fear not, my friend. I've already located and neutralized the creature. The waters are safe once more."

War and Peace-241-0.groundtruth:
Pierre Bezuhov: (smiling to himself) Ah, how good it is! How splendid!

Servant: (approaches cautiously) Are you feeling well, sir? Can I bring you anything?

Pierre Bezuhov: (looks up, still smiling) I'm very well, thank you. In fact, I've never felt better.

Servant: (hesitantly) It's good to see you in high spirits, sir. You've been through so much.

Pierre Bezuhov: Yes, I have. But you know, I've learned something important. The meaning of life... it's not in some distant goal or grand idea. It's right here, in front of us.

Servant: (nodding) If you say so, sir. Is there anything you need?

Pierre Bezuhov: (shaking his head gently) No, no. I have everything I need. Just this moment, this peace... it's enough.

Servant: (looking slightly confused) Very well, sir. I'll leave you to your rest then.

Pierre Bezuhov: (as the servant turns to leave) Wait. Tell me, are you happy? Do you find joy in your life?

Servant: (surprised) I... I suppose I am, sir. I have my health and my work. (pauses) And a family to care for.

Pierre Bezuhov: (nodding with a warm smile) That's wonderful. That's what truly matters, you know. Not grand schemes or lofty ideas, but the simple joys of living.

Servant: (smiling hesitantly) Thank you, sir. I'm glad you're feeling better. (bows slightly) I'll be nearby if you need anything.

Dracula-44-0.groundtruth:
